Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Improved Spare Parts Inventory Management in Aircraft Engines through Hybrid Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract for Collaborative Research/GOALI: Improved Spare Parts Inventory Management in Aircraft Engines through Hybrid Sensing

The objective of this GOALI award is to develop the basic science and necessary tools to transform sensor measurements from a large set of machine equipment in the field into reliable forecasts and inventory policies for the spare parts required to maintain that equipment. While equipment health monitoring is of relevance to many manufacturers, the application context of this research is commercial jet engines. The research consists of four key steps: advancing sensing methods and the interpretation of signals to diagnose engine condition; developing procedures for transforming this data into predictions of time-to-overhaul and resource-requirements; building part forecasting methods and inventory policies that aggregate this information across engines in the field, with consideration of usage and economic conditions; and creating a simulation tool for the monitoring and maintenance of a large fleet to validate the methodology.

This research will establish a framework for modeling and simulating the process of engine maintenance, and will produce theoretical results that can be translated into applicable tools of practical value to the industrial partner and the aerospace industry at large, leading to improved forecasting and inventory management for spare parts. While currently-used sensor data can provide an indication of the overall health of the engine, the advanced sensing technologies developed in this research offer the potential to predict which specific parts will need replacement before an overhaul is initiated, thus providing more time to secure the necessary resources. This research will determine the economic impact of the additional health information and improved decision-making enabled by these advanced sensing technologies, and will potentially make the case for their pervasive installation. Although the models will primarily be validated within the industrial partner's business units, they will be beneficial to a wide array of manufacturing firms for whom after-sales service is a critical component of their business.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This GOALI award has sought to develop the basic science and necessary tools to transform sensor measurements from a large set of equipment units in the field into reliable forecasts and inventory policies for the spare parts required to maintain that equipment. While equipment health monitoring is of relevance to many manufacturers, the application context of this research is commercial jet engines. The research consisted of four key steps: advancing sensing methods and the interpretation of signals to diagnose engine condition; developing procedures for transforming this data into predictions of time-to-overhaul and resource-requirements; building part forecasting methods and inventory policies that aggregate this information across engines in the field, with consideration of usage and economic conditions; and creating a simulation tool for the monitoring and maintenance of a large fleet to validate the methodology. 

These steps have been carried out through a multidisciplinary collaboration of researchers at Case Western Reserve University (PI Robert Gao), University of Nebraska Lincoln (PI Jennifer Ryan), and University of Massachusetts Amherst (PI Ana Muriel). The outcomes described below focus solely on the research performed at the University of Massachusetts on the development of a holistic simulation tool.  Collaborative work has been conducted on other tasks as well.

The key outcome of this research has been a simulation framework for engine fleet maintenance that incorporates the specific characteristics of each engine, its degradation profile, condition monitoring, economy-driven usage rates, overhaul decision thresholds, part replacement probabilities, and overhaul operations. The simulation encompasses the full lifecycle of an engine program, from engine production and entry into service over a number of initial years to engine retirements at the sunset of the program. The key performance indicators that the simulation tracks are: system inventory cost, part fill rate, maintenance fill rate (i.e. proportion of maintenance events for which all parts required are found in stock), overhaul delay, fill rate of spare engines, and aircraft on ground.

The implementation of such a holistic view of fleet overhaul operations required the identification of a number of complex decision policies; most notably: 1) a spare parts inventory ordering policy using current condition information (the main focus of this award); 2) a spare parts allocation policy to distribute a limited number of parts across the engines that require them; 3) an engine overhaul policy that determines when the engine will initiate overhaul based on the system state; and 4) a spare engine inventory policy to ensure aircraft are not grounded during engine overhaul operations. A working prototype that incorporates all these aspects is now operational, and being used to implement, test and compare a variety of policies for each of those critical decisions.  The framework has been shared with the industrial partner for validation and refinement, as well as to identify the scenarios to test. 

A necessary component for linking the sensing information to the overhaul operations and the management of spare parts is the translation of the predicted remaining useful life of the engine, which is given in flight cycles based on the condition information related by the sensors, into the calendar time when overhaul and spare parts will be needed. This requires the prediction of engine usage (cycles flown per week) over time as economic conditions change. We have developed a forecasting methodology which selects the most salient economic features out of a large data set, and then uses a regression model with ARIMA time series errors to generate a forecast of engine usage. 

The purpose of the simulation tool is three-fold: first, validation of the proposed condition-based inventory strategies; second, assessment of the operational efficiencies gained through the sensing technologies to determine the value of implementing them widely; third, strategic decision-making regarding the design and management of the system by allowing the exploration of what-if scenarios associated with different policies and system parameters. We are now in a position to use this tool to answer many interesting policy questions, at an individual level for the particular settings of our industry partner, as well as at a general level for industry guidance through carefully crafted computational experiments. This project has provided the seed for numerous future studies. 

This project has played an important role in the educational experience of the PhD, MS and undergraduate students that have, either directly or through related projects with Pratt & Whitney, contributed to it. Through participating in this project, the students have gained an understanding of the challenges in modeling and solving real-world problems, as well as the difficulties encountered when gathering and managing the necessary data. The students have developed knowledge and skills in the areas of forecasting, maintenance decision-making, inventory control, simulation, and stochastic modeling. Furthermore, the 150+ students that the PI teaches every year benefit from the practical examples/applications, as well as the research challenges and advances, brought to the classroom.
